item.title: Taking Action: Your Guide to Active Fixed Income
item.description: Active bond funds are great portfolio components because they can diversify portfolios in a time of market uncertainty. Active bond funds can have more taxable returns than other funds. When managing an active fund, the portfolio manager uses their research and expertise to hand-select stocks or bonds for the fund. Hot dog, because we’re here to give you the FYI on active fixed income funds (or active bond funds) —and why you should consider adding them to your portfolio. So active bond funds’ low costs and fees can help you hold on to more of your initial investment while you wait. Their strategic selection of funds can help your investments blossom within the market.

item.title: So You Wanna Be a Cryptonaire
item.description: Only 14% of people in the US have crypto investments, according to crypto exchange Gemini, and the market is still a pea compared to the global stock and bond markets.   Cryptocurrency isn’t just bitcoin. If you want to invest in crypto or other assets, that’s fine and dandy. But if you’re looking to diversify your portfolio and put some money in a new asset class, do some research and try starting small. The bear case: There’s a lot of speculation happening in the crypto market, and while some cryptocurrencies post huge gains, they can also be incredibly volatile. which you should already have after setting your initial investment and retirement strategy. If you sell a crypto asset, use it to purchase goods/services, or trade it for another cryptocurrency, any profit you make is probably subject to a capital gains tax (which varies based on how long the asset is held).  Just please don’t put your life savings in dogecoin. Cryptocurrency can be the bulk of those riskier investments or just a slice—but it shouldn’t be the majority of your portfolio. For crypto novices, numerous financial advisors recommend starting off with a very small allocation (1%–2%) of your portfolio in crypto. The IRS taxes cryptocurrency transactions similarly to property.   Bottom line: Unlike pairing black socks with brown loafers, there isn’t a correct answer about whether you should invest in crypto today.

item.title: It’s time to care about cryptocurrency
item.description: According to a 2021 report assessing crypto adoption in the US, 14% of the population owns cryptocurrency—and though today’s average crypto investor is exactly the stereotype your mind might conjure (late thirties, male, annual income north of $100k), tomorrow’s is more likely to be older, less wealthy, and a woman.  The price of a bitcoin as of this writing? Of course, not all of us can be as well-read as my ride-hailing friend from 2014. The price of bitcoin was about $500 or $600 back then, and most of the news headlines about cryptocurrency centered on two things: one, that crypto was used to acquire illegal goods on the black market, and two, that its value was volatile enough to vaporize a nest egg overnight—with ample evidence to back that up. He clearly had most of us beat. If sheer value isn’t justification enough to take crypto seriously, look no further than El Salvador, whose legislature in June made bitcoin legal tender in the Central American nation. In other words: It’s finally time for you, a regular person, to get educated on crypto. I’m in the backseat of an Uber, or maybe it’s a Lyft, I dunno.   But the traffic is bad to SFO and we’ve got time to kill.

item.description: Companies that enjoyed a surge in sales during the worst of the pandemic last year are confronting a new era of more socializing with people, and less socializing with an imaginary paper towel friend.    Pinterest stock plunged 18% Friday after reporting a 5% decline in global users last quarter.  Amazon, a poster child for the Covid boom, fell 7.6% Friday for their worst day in more than a year, dropping Jeff Bezos below French luxury mogul Bernard Arnault on the list of world’s richest people.
